statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following }\\ \quad f(x) = e^{\sin^{-1} x} \\ \text{with respect to x.}\\
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong? } \text{If }f(x) = e^{g(x)},\text{ then}\\ \frac{d}{dx}f(x)\text{ equals the following.}
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong? } \text{Given }\frac{d}{dx}e^{g(x)},\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\\ \text{will evaluate to the following.}
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong? }\text{ f'(x) is defined wherever}\\ \text{f(x) is defined. }

reason.tex: \begin{align} \text{If }f(x) &= e^{g(x)},\text{ then }\\ \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \underbrace{\dfrac{d}{d g(x)}e^{g(x)}\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x)}_{\text{Chain Rule}}\\ &= e^{g(x)}\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \end{align} \\ \textbf{Alternatively, } \\ \begin{align} f(x) = e^{g(x)} \implies \log f(x) &= g(x)\cdot\underbrace{\log e}_{=1} \\ \implies \dfrac{d}{dx}\log f(x) &= \dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \\ \implies\dfrac{1}{f(x)}\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \\ \implies \dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) &= \underbrace{e^{g(x)}}_{ = f(x) }\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \end{align}

\text{We know from Step 1 that }\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dx}e^{g(x)} &= e^{g(x)}\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}g(x) \\ \therefore \dfrac{d}{dx}e^{\sin^{-1}x} &= e^{\sin^{-1}x}\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}\sin^{-1}x \\ &= \dfrac{e^{\sin^{-1}x}}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \end{align}\\ \textbf{But note that }\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\text{ is defined only}\\ \text{when } 1-x^2 \neq 0\text{ and }1-x^2 \gt 0.\\ \text{ Which means, } x\in (-1,1). \\ \text{Hence, }\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\sin^{-1}x}}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}, x\in (-1,1).
